results.title: Solar dawn (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Kay Roberts, Gareth Cole and Solarscope Films
results.brief_description: Utilises many animation sequences to clearly show how basic solar collectors work. It shows how buildings can be heated and cooled by solar devices, and how city buildings and ordinary houses should be designed to take advantage of direct solar energy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kay Roberts, Gareth Cole and Solarscope Films

results.title: Man and his world: a Norwegian fjord
results.brief_description: This film concerns the gradual reconciliation of the traditional way of life with modern technology and industrial development as it has occurred in the small town of Tyssedal on the Hardangar Fjord in Norway. Once devoted solely to dairy farming, fruit growing and fishing, many of the town’s inhabitants are now employed in the huge aluminium smelting plant located at a short distance from the town. A young Tyssedal school boy and his family are among those affected by this transition in the way of life.

results.title: Dogs
results.creator_credit: Diane Belle James, Michael Murphy and Dimension Films
results.brief_description: A group of dogs in the countryside and at home. The camera observes in a sensitive and detailed way: as the dogs explore a stream and drink, we see how their tongues work to toss beads of water upwards; the rhythms and sounds, the ways of relating and communicating that are special to dogs. Includes a brief birth sequence.

results.title: Tops
results.brief_description: Tops are among man’s oldest and most popular toys. This non-narrated film features 123 spinning tops from different lands. The essence of tops is captured as the stages of their movement are displayed. The second in the unfinished trilogy of toy films (ships would have been next). Music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: Vision. [No. 28]
results.creator_credit: Ted Steeg, Ted Steeg Productions and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine: Colleges in America teach puppetry; US Patent Office grants exclusive rights to and protects all new inventions; an aerial circus; an exploration of how solar energy houses work and some examples; Girls’ Basketball Tournament in Iowa is complete with bands, beauty queens and drill teams; Thoreau’s Walden Pond philosophy he created when he lived in the wilderness.

results.title: Bridging the gap
results.brief_description: Designed to help acquire and realise the vital skills of parent-child communications. Dr Thomas Gordon, a nationally recognised authority, discusses such needs as identity, honest recognition of feelings, and courageous action as new methods of communicating, in an attempt to establish a deeper, and more intimate, relationship between parent and child.

results.title: High country
results.creator_credit: George Miller, Geoff Burrowes and Yenan Productions
results.brief_description: A group of amateur horsemen cross Victoria’s Great Dividing Range using a little frequented track. Shows without commentary, the grandeur and mystique of the region. Music by Mario Mills and Jon English

results.title: Whistle for Willie
results.creator_credit: Mal Wittman, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: The story of a little boy trying to learn how to whistle for his dog the way the older boys do is told in lovely simple words and beautiful glowing pictures. The minimal animation adds beauty to Ezra Jack Keats’ cut-paper illustrations. Story teller: Jane Harvey. From the book written and illustrated by Ezra Jack Keates.
